Pertumbuhan Ekonomi 5,02 Persen, BI: Patut Kita Acungkan Jempol
07 Nov 2019, 08:06 by Bisnis.com, Rahma Tri
TEMPO.CO, Surabaya - Deputi Gubernur Bank Indonesia Dody Budi Waluyo menanggapi angka pertumbuhan ekonomi per kuartal ketiga tahun ini sebesar 5,02 persen, atau melambat dibanding kuartal sebelumnya sebesar 5,05 persen. Ia menilai hal tersebut sebagai imbas perlambatan ekonomi global saat ini.
Perlambatan ekonomi, kata Dody, terjadi hampir di berbagai negara, termasuk Malaysia dan Singapura yang jauh lebih dalam perlambatan ekonominya. “Masalah global menjadi salah satu penyebab utama ekonomi dunia yang semuanya terdampak oleh perang dagang,” katanya di Surabaya, Kamis, 7 November 2019.
Di sisi lain, Dody menuturkan pihaknya memandang positif terhadap rilis terbaru data pertumbuhan ekonomi Indonesia triwulan III-2019 tersebut karena dinilai masih tetap terjaga dan cukup kuat di tengah pertumbuhan ekonomi dunia yang semakin melambat.
“Dalam kondisi yang penuh tantangan tersebut, kita harus bersyukur ekonomi kita tumbuh 5,02 persen. Memang melambat, tapi patut kita acungkan jempol karena masih bisa tumbuh di atas 5 persen,” ujarnya.
Dody menjelaskan, pertumbuhan ekonomi Indonesia itu didukung oleh permintaan domestik yang tetap terjaga dan kinerja sektor eksternal yang menguat di tengah permintaan dan harga komoditas global yang masih menghadapi tekanan. Dalam kondisi yang penuh dengan ketidakpastian maka paparan angka ataupun indikator makroekonomi tidak cukup untuk bisa memberi keyakinan dan gambaran optimisme yang utuh bagi pelaku usaha.
Untuk merespons tantangan perekonomian global yang semakin tidak mudah itu, menurut Dody, bank sentral akan terus mengantisipasi agar perekonomian tidak turun tajam. “Perlu sinergi bersama."
Ia pun mengimbau kepada pemerintah untuk terus memberikan stimulus bagi para pelaku usaha guna menjaga ketahanan serta tingkat keyakinan bagi mereka agar mampu memenuhi performa yang diharapkan. “Perlu dilakukan pendekatan yang lebih aktif dan persuasif kepada mereka serta stimulus usaha lainnya yang kiranya diperlukan,” katanya.

5.02 Percent Economic Growth, BI: We Give A Thumb
Nov 7 2019, 08:06 by Bisnis.com, Rahma Tri
TEMPO.CO, Surabaya - Bank Indonesia Deputy Governor Dody Budi Waluyo responded to the economic growth rate in the third quarter of this year of 5.02 percent, or slowed down from the previous quarter's 5.05 percent. He considered this as the impact of the current global economic slowdown.
The economic slowdown, said Dody, occurred in almost a number of countries, including Malaysia and Singapore, which were much more in economic slowdown. "The global problem is one of the main causes of the world economy which are all affected by the trade war," he said in Surabaya, Thursday, November 7, 2019.
On the other hand, Dody said that his party had a positive view of the release of the latest data on Indonesia's economic growth in the third quarter of 2019 because it was considered to be maintained and strong enough in the midst of slowing world economic growth.
"Under these challenging conditions, we must be grateful our economy grew 5.02 percent. It's slowing down, but we should give a thumbs up because it can still grow above 5 percent, "he said.
Dody explained, Indonesia's economic growth was supported by maintained domestic demand and the strengthening performance of the external sector amidst global demand and commodity prices that were still facing pressure. In conditions that are full of uncertainties, exposure to numbers or macroeconomic indicators is not enough to be able to provide confidence and a complete picture of optimism for business actors.
To respond to the challenges of the increasingly difficult global economy, according to Dody, the central bank will continue to anticipate that the economy does not fall sharply. "We need a synergy together."
He also appealed to the government to continue to provide stimulus for businesses to maintain their resilience and confidence to be able to meet the expected performance. "There needs to be a more active and persuasive approach to them as well as other business stimulus that would be needed," he said.
